caption.center: HENRY WOODHOUSE v. ALBERT R. HARRISON, ET AL.

opinion.syllabus:
1. REFERENCE AND COMMISSIONERS — Time of Entry of Decree ofReference — Entry Not Premature — Case at Bar. — In the instant case, a suit to foreclose a deed of trust and for a deficiency judgment, process was made returnable to the first December, 1935, rules and was personally served on the trustees, who filed their answers on November 16, 1935. Appellant, maker of the deed of trust, being a non-resident, an order of publication in due form was mailed to him and received by him on November 29, 1935, and he having failed to appear, either in person or by counsel, a decree was entered on January 13, 1936, referring the matter to a special commissioner. Appellant contended that the decree of reference was entered before the cause had matured and hence was void.
Held: That there was no merit in this contention.
2. REFERENCE AND COMMISSIONERS — Time of Entry of Decree ofReference — Entry after Resident Defendants' Answers Filed atRules Next Ensuing — Case at Bar. — In the instant case, a suit to foreclose a deed of trust and for a deficiency judgment, process was made returnable to the first December, 1935, rules and was served personally on the trustees, who filed their answers on November 16. Appellant, maker of the deed of trust, and a non-resident, although served by publication, failed to appear and the court entered a decree referring the matter to a special commissioner. Appellant contended that the decree was entered before the cause had matured and hence was void.
Held: That the trustees' answers, filed on November 16, must be treated as having been filed at the first December rules, next ensuing, and the cause was then matured as to these defendants.
3. REFERENCE AND COMMISSIONERS — Time of Entry of Decree ofReference — After Proper Order of Publication as toNon-Resident Defendant — Case at Bar. — In the instant case, a suit to foreclose a deed of trust and for a deficiency judgment, appellant, maker of the deed of trust, being a non-resident, an order of publication was published on November 29, December 6, December 13, and December 20, 1935. The order in due form was mailed to appellant and received by him on November 29, 1935, and he having failed to appear, either in person or byPage 575 counsel, a decree was entered on January 13, 1936, referring the matter to a special commissioner. Appellant contended that the decree of reference was entered before the cause had matured and hence was void.
Held: That allowing the twenty-eight days required for publication and the ten additional days required by section 6071 of the Code of 1936, the case was fully matured and ready for hearing prior to the entry of the decree of reference.
4. REFERENCE AND COMMISSIONERS — To Whom Reference Made —Reference to Special Commissioner Instead of Commissioner inChancery — Case at Bar. — In the instant case, a suit to foreclose a deed of trust and for a deficiency judgment, defendant being a non-resident an order of publication in due form was mailed to him, and he having failed to appear, either in person or by counsel, a decree was entered referring the matter to a special commissioner. Defendant contended that the matter should have been referred to one of the commissioners in chancery of the court and not to a special commissioner.
Held: That this contention was decided adversely to the defendant in Woodhouse v. Burke Herbert Bank Trust Co.,166 Va. 706, 711, 185 S.E. 876.
5. REFERENCE AND COMMISSIONERS — Motion to Vacate Decree ofReference — Duty of Commissioner to Suspend ProceedingsPending Disposition of Motion — Case at Bar. — In the instant case, a suit to foreclose a deed of trust and for a deficiency judgment, a decree was entered referring the matter to a special commissioner. Defendant made no appearance, either in person or by counsel, at the hearing before the commissioner, and at the hearing complainant fully proved the allegations of his bill and the special commissioner so reported to the court. Prior to the hearing defendant had deposited with the clerk a written motion to vacate the decree of reference and contended that the special commissioner should have suspended all hearings under the decree pending the disposition of his motion to vacate.
Held: That as there was no merit in defendant's motion to vacate, there was likewise no merit in his contention that the special commissioner should have suspended the hearings.
6. REFERENCE AND COMMISSIONERS — Motion to Vacate Decree ofReference — Mere Filing of Motion Does Not AutomaticallySuspend Proceedings. — The mere filing of a motion to vacate a decree of reference does not have the effect of automatically suspending all proceedings in the cause. If defendant desires a postponement of the hearings pending his motion to vacate, he should make a motion to that effect before the commissioner, and if the latter declines his request, he should take the matter up with the court.
7. REFERENCE AND COMMISSIONERS — To Whom Referred — Denialof Motion to Commit to Commissioner in Chancery after Referenceto Special Commissioner — Case at Bar. — In the instant case, aPage 576 suit to foreclose a deed of trust and for a deficiency judgment, a decree was entered referring the matter to a special commissioner, and on the same date the commissioner mailed to defendant a notice that he would execute the decree of reference. Defendant made no appearance, either in person or by counsel, at the hearing before the commissioner, but filed a motion to vacate the decree of reference, which motion was overruled. After a decree had been entered confirming the commissioner's report and directing a sale of the property, defendant tendered an answer and cross-bill and moved the court to commit the matter to a commissioner in chancery instead of to the special commissioner to whom the cause had been referred. The court rejected the answer and cross-bill and denied defendant's motion to commit.
Held: That as the reference to the special commissioner instead of a commissioner in chancery was proper, there was no error in the denial of defendant's motion.
8. REFERENCE AND COMMISSIONERS — Rehearing — After SaleMotion Made for Purpose of Delay Denied — Case at Bar. — In the instant case, a suit to foreclose a deed of trust and for a deficiency judgment, defendant having failed to appear, either in person or by counsel, a decree was entered referring the matter to a special commissioner. After a decree had been entered confirming the commissioner's report and directing a sale of the property, defendant tendered an answer and cross-bill and moved the court to commit the matter to a commissioner in chancery instead of to the special commissioner. The court rejected the answer and cross-bill and denied the defendant's motion to commit, but nevertheless defendant took depositions and filed in the clerk's office a motion to rehear the whole case, based on his answer and cross-bill, after the property had been sold and the report of sale was before the court for confirmation. The court offered to allow the answer and cross-bill to be filed, but made it plain that should it find no merit in the case of defendant, then the proceedings and decrees theretofore entered would stand. Defendant declined to proceed on this basis and insisted that all proceedings be set aside, whereupon the court overruled the motion for a rehearing and confirmed the sale of the property.
Held: No error, as the court, being convinced that defendant was not acting in good faith, but was merely attempting to delay the cause, had the right to decline a rehearing of the entire matter at that stage of the proceedings.
9. MORTGAGES AND DEEDS OF TRUST — Foreclosure — Sale forCash or Credit — Case at Bar. — In the instant case, a suit to foreclose a deed of trust and for a deficiency judgment, appellant contended that the court erred in decreeing that the property should be sold for cash. The deed of trust provided that it should be "construed in accordance with the provisions of section 5167 of the Code of Virginia." Appellant contended that the statutePage 577 formerly directed the trustee, in the absence of other provisions in the deed of trust, to sell for cash alone, and that when the legislature amended the statute and directed the property to be sold "upon such terms and conditions as the trustee may deem best," by implication this deprived the trustee of the right to sell for cash.
Held: That there was no merit in this contention, as prior to the amendment of the statute the power to sell upon such terms and conditions as the trustee might deem best was usually written in deeds of trust and construed to include the power to sell either for cash or on time, and obviously it was the purpose of the legislature to have the language of the statute conform to the accepted practice, thus broadening and not restricting the powers of the trustee.
10. MORTGAGES AND DEEDS OF TRUST — Foreclosure — Judgmentfor Deficiency — Case at Bar. — In the instant case, a suit to foreclose a deed of trust, defendant complained of the action of the court in entering a personal judgment against him for the amount remaining due on the trust indebtedness after the application of the net proceeds of the sale thereto. The bill contained a prayer for a deficiency judgment, and defendant made a general appearance. The court found that the property had been sold at a fair price, that the moneys had been properly applied, and that there was a balance, with interest, remaining unpaid on the indebtedness.
Held: That it was entirely proper that a personal judgment should have been entered for the amount, with interest, remaining unpaid on the indebtedness.
opinion.posture:
Appeal from a decree of the Circuit Court of Fairfax county, in a suit to foreclose a deed of trust and for a deficiency judgment. Hon. Walter T. McCarthy, judge presiding.
Affirmed.
The opinion states the case.
opinion.attorneys:
Raymond M. Hudson, Minor Hudson and Geoffrey Creyke, Jr., for the appellant.
Albert V. Bryan, for the appellees.
opinion.opinion_byline: EGGLESTON, J., delivered the opinion of the court.
opinion.opinion_text:
On November 11, 1935, Albert R. Harrison filed his bill in the Circuit Court of Fairfax county against Henry Woodhouse,Page 578 Robinson Moncure, trustee, and Wilson M. Farr, trustee. The bill alleged that by deed dated November 9, 1932, Henry Woodhouse had conveyed to Moncure and Farr, as trustees, certain land in Fairfax county to secure an indebtedness of $3,500 evidenced by seven promissory notes, each made and signed by Henry Woodhouse, each held by the complainant, and each past due and unpaid.
The bill prayed for a foreclosure of the said deed of trust, the sale of the property, the application of the proceeds to the payment of the indebtedness, and for a personal judgment against the defendant, Henry Woodhouse, for any deficiency.
Process was made returnable to the first December, 1935, rules and was served personally on the defendant trustees, Moncure and Farr, who, on November 16, 1935, filed their answers concurring in the prayers of the bill.
The defendant, Woodhouse, being a non-resident, an order of publication in due form was entered, posted, published and mailed as to him as required by Code, sections 6069 and 6070. The copy mailed to this defendant at his residence in New York was actually received by him on November 29, 1935.
Woodhouse having failed to appear either in person or by counsel, on January 10, 1936, a decree was entered referring the matter to a special commissioner to ascertain and report the usual pertinent matters.
On the same date the commissioner mailed to the defendant, Woodhouse, at his said residence in New York, a notice that he would proceed to execute the decree of reference at his office, at Alexandria, at 3:00 p.m. on January 23, 1936. Although Woodhouse received this notice on January 17, he made no appearance, either in person or by counsel, at the hearing before the commissioner. At this hearing the complainant fully proved the allegations of his bill and the special commissioner so reported to the court on February 7.
In the meantime, on January 20, Woodhouse, through Raymond M. Hudson, Esq., an attorney residing and practicing in Washington, D.C., had deposited with the clerk a written motion to vacate the decree of reference theretofore entered. The grounds of the motion were (1) that the decree wasPage 579 entered before the cause had matured and hence was void, and (2) that the matter should have been referred to one of the commissioners in chancery of the court and not to a special commissioner. Later Woodhouse moved to reject the report of the special commissioner on the same grounds.
Although the court had been in session in the meantime, the defendant, Woodhouse, took no steps to have these motions disposed of until February 27 when the special commissioner's report came on to be heard. At this time the motions were fully argued and the court announced its determination to overrule them. This decision was embodied in a decree entered on March 11.
While Woodhouse took no exceptions to the ruling of the court on his motions with respect to the decree of reference, one of his principal assignments of error challenges the correctness of such ruling.
[1] There is no merit in the contention that the entry of the decree of reference on January 13 was premature and before the cause had matured.
[2] As we have seen process was served in person on the two resident defendants, Moncure and Farr, trustees, and they filed their answers on November 16. Treating these as having been filed at the first December rules, next ensuing, as we must(Goddin v. Vaughn's Ex'x, 14 Gratt. (55 Va.) 102, 130; FirstNat. Bank v. Huntington, etc., Co., 41 W. Va. 530, 23 S.E. 792, 793, 56 Am.St. Rep. 878), the cause was then matured as to these defendants. Code, section 6138.
[3] As to the non-resident defendant, Woodhouse, an order of publication in due form was entered, published, posted and mailed as required by Code, sections 6069 and 6070.
Under the express provisions of Code, section 6071, "When such order shall have been so executed, or when a copy of any process, or of a notice beginning any action, shall have been published as provided by any section of this chapter, if the defendants against whom it is entered, or published, or the unknown parties, shall not appear within ten days after the completion of the execution of such order, or the expirationPage 580 of the four weeks required for the completion of such publication, the case may be tried or heard as to them, * * *."
The order of publication was published on November 29, December 6, December 13, and December 20. So, allowing the twenty-eight days required for the publication (Dillard v.Krise, 86 Va. 410, 412, 10 S.E. 430), and the ten additional days required by Code, section 6071, the case had fully matured and was ready for hearing as to the defendant, Woodhouse, before the entry of the decree of January 13. See Barton's Chancery Practice (3d Ed.), pp. 157, 158.
[4] The next contention of the appellant that the court had no right to refer the matter to a special commissioner instead of a commissioner in chancery was decided adversely to this same appellant in Woodhouse v. Burke Herbert Bank TrustCo., 166 Va. 706, 711, 185 S.E. 876.
[5] Since there was no merit in the defendant's motion to vacate the decree of reference, there is likewise no merit in his contention that the special commissioner should have suspended all hearings under the decree pending the disposition of said motion.
[6] Furthermore, the mere filing of the motion to vacate said decree did not have the effect of automatically suspending all proceedings in the cause, as the appellant seems to think. If he desired a postponement of the hearings pending his motion to vacate the decree, he should have made a motion to that effect before the commissioner, and if the latter had declined his request he should have taken the matter up with the court which was then in session.
[7] After a decree had been entered confirming the report of the special commissioner and directing a sale of the property, the defendant, Woodhouse, tendered an answer and cross-bill and moved the court to commit the matter "to a commissioner in chancery," — not to the special commissioner to whom the cause had been referred, — in order that the defendant might take evidence in support of the allegations in such answer and cross-bill. The court rejected the answer and cross-bill and denied the defendant's motion to commit.
We have already seen that the reference to a special commissionerPage 581 instead of a commissioner in chancery was proper. Hence there was no error in the denial of the defendant's motion here.
Despite this action of the court Woodhouse proceeded to take the depositions of certain witnesses, and after these had been completed he filed in the clerk's office a motion to rehear the whole case, based on the same answer and cross-bill and on the depositions taken in support thereof.
This motion came on to be heard on May 21. In the meantime the property had been sold at public auction, knocked down to the complainant, Albert R. Harrison, and the commissioner's report of such sale was before the court for confirmation or rejection.
By this time the court had evidently come to the conclusion that the defendant was seeking delay rather than justice. Nevertheless, with the consent of the complainant, the court offered to allow the answer and cross-bill to be filed and to grant a rehearing and a trial thereon with the depositions in support thereof, and if upon such hearing it should find for the defendant, Woodhouse, then it would set aside all proceedings and decrees theretofore had and entered in the cause. But the court also made it plain that should it find upon such hearing that there was no merit in the case of Woodhouse, as made out in his answer and cross-bill and depositions, then the proceedings and decrees theretofore had and entered would stand.
Woodhouse declined to proceed on this basis and insisted that all prior proceedings in the cause be set aside before the hearing on his cross-bill and answer and depositions. Whereupon the court overruled his motion for a rehearing and confirmed the sale of the property.
[8] We perceive no error in this action of the court. Being convinced that the defendant was not acting in good faith, but was merely attempting to delay the cause, the court had the right to decline a rehearing of the entire matter at that stage of the proceedings, — four months after Woodhouse had entered a general appearance in the cause, and after the property had been sold. The offer to re-open the cause underPage 582 the conditions stated was, therefore, more than Woodhouse was entitled to.
While no such contention was made in the court below, in the argument before us counsel for Woodhouse contended that to have accepted the offer of the court would have caused him "to waive his entire right to his equity of redemption" of the property.
In reply to this argument the appellee, Harrison, the holder of the debt secured and the purchaser of the property at the foreclosure sale, through his counsel, offered to Woodhouse the opportunity of redeeming the property even at that late date upon the payment of the debt secured, with interest and costs. However, this proposition was not accepted and nothing came of the suggested compromise settlement.
The appellant next contends that the court erred in decreeing that the property should be sold for cash. The deed of trust provided that it should be "construed in accordance with the provisions of section 5167 of the Code of Virginia." Here the argument is that the statute formerly directed the trustee, in the absence of other provisions in the deed of trust, to sell for cash alone; that when the legislature amended the statute (Acts 1926, ch. 324, p. 591) and directed that the property be sold "upon such terms and conditions as the trustee may deem best," by implication this deprived the trustee of the right to sell for cash.
[9] This contention is without merit. Even before the incorporation in the statute of the present authority to sell "upon such terms and conditions as the trustee may deem best," such power was usually written in deeds of trust in this State. And from time immemorial such language has been interpreted by the profession to include the power to sell either for cash or on time. Obviously it was the purpose of the legislature to have the language of the statute conform to the accepted practice, and thus to broaden and not to restrict the powers of the trustee.
[10] The appellant complains of the action of the court in entering a personal decree against him for the amount remaining due on the deed of trust indebtedness after the application of the net proceeds of the sale thereto.Page 583
The bill contained a prayer for such a deficiency judgment. It is conceded that Woodhouse made a general appearance in the suit. The court found that the property had been sold at a fair price, that the moneys had been properly applied, and that there was a balance of $692.37, with interest, remaining unpaid on the indebtedness. It was entirely proper, therefore, that a personal judgment should have been entered for this amount.
It would serve no good purpose to undertake to discuss the other assignments of error. Suffice it to say that we have carefully considered each of them and find no error in any of the decrees appealed from. Such decrees are accordingly
Affirmed.Page 584
